comments.commentBody:
In my opinion, losing the ability to speak your parents language does not necessarily indicate successful assimilation. It could mean other things. For some it could indicate apprehension regarding their success in a new country and as a result suppress the native language in a household. Losing ones cultural ties and language so rapidly in a single generation is unfortunate. Retaining a bit of culture and at least some language is an enrichment to oneself and society. I consider cultural assimilation successful regardless of ones ability to speak your parents language. It's a succes if you're able to speak the language and contribute to your family's new home country.

I feel for the american kid. Though his spanish skills may not be at the same level as his mexican peers and is struggling living in mexican society, I hope he'll find success despite it being difficult in a land of few opportunities. Perhaps one day the concentrated wealth in mexico will trickle down to the rest of society in developing a more viable economy for everyday people.

Let's just hope Jeffrey finds success with his his bi-lingual skills in a benevolent transnational enterprise instead of the murderous kind when he's all grown up and looking for work.

Army brats don't go through this..as far as I know, military are not deported to Iraq or Germany...
Their kids go to American school abroad were no locals will dare to call them diminutives name.
In addition to that, those army brats will be able to come back home after a few years.
Making the comparison between military expats and deported illegals immigrants shows an abyssal lack of comprehension of the problem.

I was deeply touched to read that this boy is living without McDonald's--I thought its golden arches had become inescapable in Mexico. I'll have to check out his town. Anyway, even before deportations, there was a large expat community in Mexico and a number of schools that cater to them. If the kid can't learn Spanish, he has other options than studying abroad. Why doesn't the Times write a story about the army brats and children of expats who go through this all over the world?

You are the one who misses the point.

"If you had a chance for a promotion that would benefit your family, I am sure you would try and obtain it."

Every single day, I bypass opportunities to STEAL things that would help provide a better or easier life for my family. Mr. Isidoro did not pass up those opportunities. He stole the livelihood of a legal resident family whose father would have been a CARPENTER. That is, unless the enablers of illegal aliens are now claiming that Americans and legal residents are too sorry to work as carpenters.

The simple and basic rules of supply and demand apply to labor just as they do to other products and services. When you inflate the supply of labor, the price of labor goes down. When wages and benefits for workers go down, consumer demand goes down. When consumer demand goes down, more workers get laid off.

Apparently, you are the one who is uneducated about immigration law. Over 1 million immigrants are legally admitted every year. Please tell us how many of the aspiring 2 BILLION immigrants in this world should be admitted every year?

If the "undocumented are just people like us, who love, want to learn and grow, and provide the best possible life for their children", why did they have children when they could not legally provide for them?

America cannot provide jobs for the whole world.

Hi, here's my experience of working illegally in the United State:

From January 2000 to July 2000, I worked illegally in California:
I started looking for work unaware that a work permit was necessary , until a carpenter asked me if I had a green card and if I belonged to a union ...I eventually find a job in a sandwich shop working 10-12 a day for 6usd/ h..The owner was working for a second person but I never saw anybody remotely American applying for the job.After two months, I find another job in a coffee downtown waiting table and serving pastry, I was paid 8usd/h + tip, way better than my first job.
The owner was constantly looking for waiter, but again no desperate US citizen showing up, not even the shadow of one.
Then, and this is the interesting part, I found another job at night in a striptease club as a doorman. The job involved from 6pm to 5 am denying entry to any body on substance.you got the picture.
I paid taxes on my salary (about 400 per months), but I couldn't get any benefits of course. I was in fact contrary as to what the good folk implies here, paying into the system without benefiting of it.You can then imagine the plus value of having millions of illegals employees paying into US wealth fare without ever taking a nickel out of the system.
So when complaining about not receiving enough benefits and blaming Pedro for it, could you instead check how much your state spend on defense /prison/ pension program before.

For those who missed the point, this story is about how immigration is effecting children. While trying to protect them, some parents don't realize the longterm effects of the decisions they make. I am sure when the undocumented adults come over here it is not because they are trying to break the law. It is a hard life in Mexico. Some have little to no education so they come to America for something better for their children and themselves. If you had a chance for a promotion that would benefit your family, I am sure you would try and obtain it. For some coming to America is that chance at a promotion. Would you not risk everything if the children you loved were suffering in their current situation. There is no such thing as wellfare or foodstamps are traffic laws. I am sure most undocumented adults don't even realize their even breaking the law with a broken tail light. They are just happy to have a car, to go to work, and put food on the table. It is a game of survival. If it was really easy to get a green card don't you think more of the undocumented would get them. Immigration is all about money not about the betterment of people. We need a total overhaul of our immigration system. The American People are so uneducated when it comes to immigration laws because the never had to deal with them. I just wish people could understand that the undocumented are just people like us, who love, want to learn and grow, and provide the best possible life for thier children.

Andy,

Nice of you to take a minute to answer this guy, but, frankly, his knowledge of climate basics is so abysmal that I think it's hardly worth responding to. He makes wmar look like Einstein.

Please be specific about what an ordinary working person can do about any of this, other than try to be a good parent and good neighbor, not patronize trash, and try to vote for someone good (who often turns out to be the best liar.)

Blaming people who spend all their time and energy barely making it seems rather unfair, actually.
any trainer who administers this narcotic to a horse and then races the animal should be arrested for cruelty to an animal

Roger Clemens worked hard all his life. He was falsely accused and had the guts and took the risk to testify and say the report was a lie. The guys accusing him were proven liars and the DOJ Prosecutors wanted to become famous getting a big star. They do not care if he is innocent they get to say he lied so they decide to prosecute. They got people to lie or also be indicted as they do so often. They went along with fabricated evidence presented by the key false witness.

The Government (DOJ) witnesses lie all the time. No one ever goes after a government witness who lies. Why? The DOJ is not going to go after their witnesses who lie against the person they decide to go after. The fox is watching the hen house and no one seems to notice it. I have not heard any reporters or people say that maybe the DOJ should go after the people who did lie like the DOJ witnesses.

Roger Clemens was innocent when indicted, was found innocent after trial and now deserves to be called innocent. How dare people question if he deserves the Hall of Fame. He is not tainted he is innocent.

He does not deserve to have people say he got away with something. He was found not guilty and deserves to be left alone.

He is a leader and hard worker. That is good not bad. When did America start hating good people? It is wrong to assume guilt before trial but really wrong to assume guilt after trial.

Send letters/print comments supporting Clemens. It is wrong to tear him down.

Nevertheless, they are regarded as Greek philosophers because they spoke Greek, were Grecian subjects, lived in Greek colonies, had Greek parents, etc. If asked to declare their allegiance for the philosopher's world cup, they may well have affiliated with Greece on the basis of intellectual, not geographic tradition.

Not incidentally, there was no Italy at the time. There was Rome and those philosophers were not, so far as I know, Roman. Whether their dna can be firmly attributed to ethnic Roman, Sicilian, Calabrian, or ethnic Greek heritage is, however, irrelevant.

If you're making a joke, we get it. But, if you're rebutting a joke with corrections like those and you're probably wrong...

Actually Parmenides, Zeno, Archimedes, and Empedocles were from Southern Italy. Pythagoras lived most of his life in Crotone, Italy.

Go Azzuri.

I loved this puzzle. Spoonerisms are always fun.

Mac
I agree. It's exasperating to be honest, and gives false hope.

Use of other lipids as a control is well documented. Olive oil would not have "prevented" CVDs in this particular group of patients who were already suffering from cardiovascular disease, hence an acceptable placebo.

I, for one, would not have been comfortable giving saturated fats to these group of patients just to approximate the average composition of the fat intake of the population as a whole.

The photo is so classic 1970s, it suddenly reminded me of my own friend back then who had a severely overweight mother.  She smoked and used diet pills and nothing worked.  She had been a beautiful woman - like Peggy Lee- and still took great care with her looks--frosted hair, thick eyeliner, long, perfect nails.   She was open hearted and giving.  When I ran away from home at 16, although she had 8 of her own children, she welcomed me in.  They did not eat well either-- she hated to cook, and I remember plastic cups and paper plates, hot dogs and take out pizza.  The 70s were the fun feminist years-- when women could first happily say they hated cooking and not be viewed as lacking required feminine skills.   It was liberating.  My sisters, in high school in the 60s, had to take Home Ec--they were going to be home cooking for families.  By the time I went in the 70s, the class was an elective and barely attended.  You really have to look at the photo and understand the times, not just criticize from 40 years later.

Growing up in the 50's and 60's, I am too old for Title IX to have affected me as a student. Girls did not play sports, take wood shop, or wear pants to school. Although I likely would not have chosen to play, and certainly would not have been much good at, any sport, I still resented it. It was not fair, and my friends who could and would have played did suffer. And -20 is too cold for a dress.

My sister, though, is ten years younger and wore pants in addition to playing several sports in school and out. I benefited through the advantages Title IX brought her.

Title IX also made me want to be the mother of a daughter, and when she was born it enabled me to give her the choices I hadn't had. It also gave her brother the opportunity to see girls as his equals in many areas, not least sports.

I might even say it helped them have the option of voting for many more female candidates--we have women for our governor, both U.S. Senators, and a Congressperson, in addition to having had Ms. Clinton as a presidential candidate.

Even in the world of these 20-somethings, the playing fields are not level yet, but they are much better. My son's boss and coworker in tech are both women, as is the head of my daughter's college. To them having women in positions of power is as natural as was their easy acceptance of equality of the sexes as they were growing up.

Perhaps you need to redefine 'exercise'.
I like to swim; it's relaxing. I have a bike (adult trike actually - very useful and way cool), because in addition to saving gas, I love sailing along through the wind. I don't mind stationary biking at the gym if I have a book to prop on the handlebars. I do nautilus, but that reward is more like Dorothy Parker's quip that she hated writing but loved having written; I hate weightlifting but love having lifted weights and developed the strength. Gardening, yardwork, and housework also count.
And I do notice that although some people at my gym smile while they work out (I smile when I swim), the treadmillers are never among the smilers! If you must walk for exercise, walk to a place (other than Dunkin' Doughnuts, of course ;} ).

Here's my theory, people that say they love exericise have simply managed to fool themselves, albeit for the better. I prefer pretty much everything except the dentist and listening to a co-worker's wierd opinions --you do  know that every co-ed at NYU (my graduate school) Columbia and Yale hates men, don't you-- to working out,.  I really don't get how someone can say  that 45 minutes on a treadmill (yuck), or on  a stairmaster (double yuck) is ever so much fun.  I'd rather read the paper, hang with friends or even taking a nap   I attend  a small-group Pilates reformer class twice weekly because of osteoarthritis in my back...I do see a physical  benefit, and that is why I go (plus I pay extra for the classes, so not going is a waste). But I hate hate hate  going to that class, despite the great teacher, and nice atmosphere (our newly rehabbed JCC), and all the folks I run into and chat with there.  I just keep thinking of all the other things I could do, things I enjoy far more.  I realize I "should" add  cardio if I want to lose wieght and cut my  cholesteral, but jeez, I cannot take anymore excercise than the two hours a week I do!

◎ Brain Behav Immun. 2012 May 26.
Omega-3 supplementation lowers inflammation in healthy middle-aged and older adults: A randomized controlled trial
: JK Kiecolt-Glaser et al.

"...placebo was a mixture of palm, olive, soy, canola, and coco butter oils that approximated the saturated : monounsaturated : polyunsaturated (SMP) ratio consumed by US adults."

◎ N Engl J Med. 2010 Nov 18.
n-3 fatty acids and cardiovascular events after myocardial infarction.
: Kromhout D, Giltay EJ, Geleijnse JM; Alpha Omega Trial Group.

"...a margarine supplemented with a combination of EPA and DHA (with a targeted additional daily intake of 400 mg of EPA-DHA), a margarine supplemented with ALA (with a targeted additional daily intake of 2 g of ALA), a margarine supplemented with EPA-DHA and ALA, or a placebo margarine..."

Use of other lipids as a control is well documented and is an acceptable form of control in a large scale study such as this when deciding how a specific lipid can confer a beneficial effect that no other lipids gives. I see neither a mistake or intention to discredit as you seem to think.

As a long term survivor (25+ years) of HIV, I have been cared for by what is supposed to be a esteemed clinic. I have been on a antiretroviral  meds for a dozen years. About 5 years ago my Dr. started to get back very high levels of cholesteral on my regular blood labs. So, her reaction was to warn me about eating "too many cheese burgers"! In the following 3 years I cut out every possible offending thing I could think of, no cheese, little meat...definately no cheeseburgers.  I am a VERY youthful HEALTHY man, that has always monitored my health very closely, and regularly work out , with a tight trim body. Still,this situation was blamed on me, and my "Bad diet". Then one afternoon, I had a heartattack! Luckily it was a minor one, and I had a stint placed in my chest. I returned to my Clinic, with reason to believe that this situation might be caused by my meds; so I asked to be changed to another drug regime.  They just would not listen to me, so I forced the issue, and quit my meds.  Finally, I got a new regime...and you know what? The next blood work I had done my cholesteral levels PLUMMETED TO A QUARTER OF WHAT THEY HAD BEEN, and stayed that way ever since.  I know some of these Dr. are working really hard to get things right, but experience in this world of HIV Clinics has shown me that HIV has become more a cash cow for Pharmaceutical Companies, with common sense and compassion a secondary thought, far too often.
I don't even understand what this means.
And the man - what should he do?

You seem to blame this suffering solely on the falsely identified man. Sadly far too often both the father and mother are uncertain who is the father. This can only increase the tension and parental conflict.

DNA testing should be mandatory, at least outside of marriage. This would take the onus off of the father who is otherwise placed in the horrible position of telling the mother he doesn't trust her. Few mothers tell the man involved that someone else might be the father. However, nationally about 30% of men identified as the father are excluded in DNA testing.

Phil Holman
HolmanFamilyLaw.com

Every case is unique. For me, the welfare of the child always comes first.  If that happens because the non father helps to raise the child well, while ignorant that he is not the father, then that may be the best outcome. If 30% of putative fathers are identified as not the fathers, I doubt that human happiness will show a net increase.  The statistic should be suppressed. Men are going to   be looking at women with increased suspicion.

Many putative fathers are going to pressure pregnant women to take the test, in order to find out if they are the fathers. When they are not,  it will often be the innocent children who will be the principal sufferers.

Etienne Rosas, as a New York City public school teacher for 21 years I have met many people like those described in the article.  You are  very condescending to assume that I haven't had experiences with illegals.  You are writing from Paris, France - enjoy.  I will b there this summer as I am every year.  It's nice to be in a European country, isn't it?

All very good comments.  Perhaps I am cold or just insensitive out of that comes the following assessment.   What is the responsibility of an individual or a family a community or a country to anyone who don't initially belong to that group.  Would you as a person adopt more kids who are starving from around the world or just here in the US and bring them up or would you save up for your kids future?  The same argument applies to a community and to a country.  Should the United States welcome all starving immigrants from everywhere in the world?  Also if we are doing that should we not allow more people from Africa instead of just from Mexico.  Why should Mexican illegal immigrants get all the breaks.  The US should set up a quota for illegal immigrants and get them from all over the world, Maybe more from Somalia because they are facing starvation there.
Illegals should be deported.  Illegal is illegal.

How about the converse? The many young children here in the US brought into this society that looks down on them likewise suffer. Many are taught to live in the shadows with the overhanging fear that they or a loved one could be deported, taught not report crimes or abuse for fear of attracting official lawful attention. Maybe another article from the NY Times will illuminate their plight.

For all we know, Dottie may be a victim or Dottie may be as warped as her husband. It may be a match of two sadly warped people whose psyches reciprocally filled each others' misshapen needs. Jerry Sandusky sounds terribly damaged; it would be strange if his wife were the picture of robust mental health. It takes energy to ignore and rationalize odd behavior, and I find it hard to believe that for 45 years she never suspected a thing. If the allegations are true (I haven't followed this story closely, but it seems likely they are), she must be held to account for her inaction, too. To frame this as a feminist issue misses the point and does not help the young men who have the guts to confront their rapist.

You are of course right that children are mistreated every day, sometimes in plain sight and under the rules set by adults. I hate seeing this around me, too. But doing what we can in our own lives to right these wrongs does not let Dottie off the hook.

If the earth were not an electrically equipotential surface, you could make a bundle by using the voltage difference between Philadelphia and Atlanta and a very high conductive wire to harvest the electrical energy. Also, in areas of higher potential, your hair would stand on end even if you were touching a local ground.

Lastly, I'd like to talk about Lightning. The air is a far better insulator than the earth and it can build up charge. This can cause the local opposite charge of the earth to build up near where the air is charged. The earth's charge is caused by electrons migrating towards (or away) from the electric field caused by the charged air. It is this flow of electricity in the earth and build up of a static charge (this is analogous to a capacitor) that causes your hair to stand up on end, and in some cases, for lightning to strike. This charge, per Gauss' law for conducting objects, will be on its surface.

In this situation, some objects -- those at higher elevations, with sharp point, and better conductors -- will build up greater charge. But that is in response to the charged atmosphere, not the fundamental potentials of the earth.

I hope that I have given enough examples to allow your mind to wrap around the how grounding works

Continued in Reply #2
